question: Question_08
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} Justify your answers and \textbf{show
all your work.} \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of
numerical answers is required in these questions.}

A light sits atop a post \emph{H} meters high, and a person of height
\emph{h}, where $H > h$, walks along a straight line away from the
lamppost at a speed of \emph{v} m/s. At what rate is the
person$^{\prime}$s shadow lengthening?
sols:
To get started, we draw a diagram and label with variables.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math100_December_2012_Problem_8_Solution.jpg}
\caption{Math100 December 2012 Problem 8 Solution.jpg}
\end{figure}

Note that \emph{H} and \emph{h} (the height of the lamppost and the
person) are constant but \emph{x} and \emph{y} (the distance of the
person from the lamppost, and the length of the person's shadow) are
changing.

We relate all the variables in the above picture by using similar
triangles:

$\frac{y}{h} = \frac{x+y}{H}$

Cross-multiplying gives

$\displaystyle yH = xh + yh$

If we differentiate with respect to time, we get

$H  \frac{dy}{dt} = h\frac{dx}{dt} + h\frac{dy}{dt}$

(Recall that H, h are constants, so they aren't differentiated.)

The question is asking us for the rate at which the person's shadow is
changing, which is the same as the rate at which \emph{y} is changing,
or $dy/dt$. So we solve the above expression for $dy/dt$.

$H  \frac{dy}{dt}  - h\frac{dy}{dt}= h\frac{dx}{dt}$

$\frac{dy}{dt}  (H - h) = h\frac{dx}{dt}$

$\frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{h\frac{dx}{dt}}{H - h}$

The rate \emph{v} that is given in the question is the speed at which
the person is walking, i.e. the rate at which \emph{x} changes, so:

$\frac{dx}{dt} = v$

Plugging this into our previous formula, we get

$\frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{h v}{H - h}$

which is the final answer.
